subject: BoJ minutes from June 14th-15th meeting states momentum to achieving price target was being maintained
content:
Says:
- Most members viewed BoJ would continue with QQE with Yield Curve Control, aiming to achieve the price stability target of 2% as long as it was necessary for maintaining that target in a stable manner,
- Some members said must continue to carefully assess effects of low rates on banks.
- One member said must scrutinize positive and negative side effects of policy considering that it will take a while to reach inflation goal. 

Full link to minutes: http://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/minu_2018/g180615.pdf

subject: Scotiabank says it sees BOC hiking rates at a faster pace due to improved outlook, sees next hike in September and another in December
PREVIEW: BoJ minutes from June 14th-15th meeting due at 0050BST/1850CDT/0750HKT
content:
The BoJ are to release the minutes from the June meeting, where the central bank kept monetary policy unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.10% and the 10yr yield target maintained at around 0%.

At the meeting, the BoJ cut its assessment on inflation in which it stated that inflation expectations are proceeding sideways and that CPI is in range of 0.5%-1.0%, while the BoJ kept assessment of Japan's economy unchanged in which it states Japan's economy is expanding moderately. Furthermore, the previously released Summary of Opinions from the June meeting stated it is appropriate to pursue powerful monetary easing with persistence under the current guideline as inflation a long way to price target.

Today’s release is not expected to impact markets given that the decision itself and Summary of Opinions was met with a muted reaction, while there has also been a more recent earlier this week, in which the BoJ kept the bank rate at -0.1% and the long-term yield target at around 0.0% but announced more flexibility and adopted forward guidance on rates which it says will be maintained at very low levels for extended period.

UK

BoE August Meeting Summary: BoE voted 9-0 to lift rates by 25bps from 0.50% to 0.75%. (Newswires)
Vote split on corporate bonds: 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of corporate bonds
Vote split on APF: 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of UK government bond purchases
BoE stated that since the May QIR, the near-term outlook has evolved broadly in-line with the MPC’s expectations and recent data appears to confirm that the dip in output in Q1 was temporary with momentum recovering Q2.
BoE also commented that were the economy to develop broadly inline with the August QIR projections, an ongoing tightening of monetary policy over the forecast period would be warranted but added any future rate rises are likely to be gradual and to a limited extent.

BoE QIR Forecasts:
GDP Growth: 2018 Q3: 1.5% (Prev.1.4%), 2019 Q3: 1.8% (Prev. 1.7%), 2020 Q3: 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%), 2021 Q3: 1.7%
CPI Inflation: 2018 Q3: 2.5% (Prev. 2.4%), 2019 Q3: 2.2% (Prev. 2.1%), 2020 Q3: 2.1% (Prev. 2.0%), 2021 Q3: 2.0%

BoE Governor Carney said that one rate hike a year for the next few years will more or less get inflation back to the 2% target over the horizon. Carney also stated there is a wide range of outcomes for Brexit, in many of them, rates will be at least as high as now, but later added the BoE is prepared to cut interest rates back again depending upon how Brexit negotiations go.

GBP initially rose on the decision and the unanimous vote to hike rates, although sellers then emerged during the press conference with Governor Carney. There have been a number of narratives offered for the selling, with the Bank stressing that any future rate rises are likely to be gradual and limited (as it has suggested previously), and the current market rate path is flatter than it was in May, implying a rate of 0.9% in one-year (ie. another hike by then), 1.0% in two-years and 1.1% in three-years. Perhaps it was due to Carney once again flagging up Brexit risks suggesting that there is a wide range of outcomes for Brexit, if there is a major shift due to Brexit talks that is deflationary, or creates an extreme trade-off, that could have consequences for monetary policy. The net result was GBP conceding the 1.31 handle and just managed to keep to the 1.30 level.

EU's Chief Brexit Negotiator Barnier tweeted Brexit negotiations can reach a good outcome, while there were also reports that Barnier was willing to “improve the text” of his proposal for an Irish backstop solution. (Newswires/FT)

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI Jul 55.8 vs. Exp. 52.8 (Prev. 53.1). (Newswires)


FX

Mexico Central Bank maintained rates at 7.75% as expected, in an unanimous decision. The Board said it will maintain prudent policy stance going forward, and it will follow closely the potential pass through from the peso, relative monetary stance with the US, as well as domestic slack. It also repeated its language that the balance of risks to inflation had an upward bias and balance of risks to growth has a downward bias. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

China will impose a 50% steel production cut in six cities (including Tangshan and Handan) during the heating season and will impose no less than 30% of steel capacity cuts in other cities in the region. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

US stocks were mostly higher with gains led by tech after Apple (AAPL) became the first USD 1tln company as shares breached 207.04. McDonald’s (MCD) were hit after reports in Business Insider that 350 French Branches have cases of Listeria. In terms, Tesla (TSLA) lost more than was expected, however, its revenues beat expectations. Tesla’s cash outflow fell from $390mln in Q1 to $130mln in Q2 and also stated most of the cost restructuring took place in Q2, and it announced in the following quarter it expects to produce 50-55k Model 3s, but said the deliveries should exceed that; it also announced it will be sustainably profitable from Q3 onwards. After the report, CEO Elon Musk apologised to analysts for his ‘bad behaviour’ in the last conference call where he stated the questions were ‘boring and bonehead’. The apology did benefit the stock as in aftermarket trade share price surged further to highs of ~11%. T-Mobile (TMUS) also reported an EPS beneath the consensus view, but revenues were stronger. SPX +0.5% at 2827, NDX +1.36% at 7372, DJI -0.03% at 25328.

Treasuries were higher and the curve modestly bull-steepened on Thursday. There was some selling action after a weak JGB auction overnight, and after the BOE’s rate decision, the complex also found sellers in the first instance. Analysts at IGM suggested that there was some short-covering ahead of Friday’s payrolls data, while the belly of the curve was bolstered by a block trade in the five-year space. US 10YR T-notes settled higher by 5 ticks at 119-10+.

US MARKET WRAP - 2 Aug 2018: Apple hits $1trln valuation; BOE hikes but GBP falls; Banxico on hold
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries modestly bull-steepen, crude higher, dollar higher.
* REAR-VIEW: Apple hits $1trln valuation; BOE lifts rates, but pound falls.  
* COMING-UP: Australian retail sails overnight and US nonfarm payrolls expected to show 195k added in July

* TRADE: US Commerce Secretary Ross said that possible tariffs on Chinese imports would not be cataclysmic, says Trump feels it is potentially time to put more pressure on China with possible new tariffs. With regards to Europe, Ross said that the US intends to complete research on auto tariffs, but will only implement them if negotiations with the EU fail. Earlier, China’s MOFCOM said they are to 'properly handle' trade disputes with the US, and will take every effort to stabilize trade. And ahead of bilateral NAFTA talks between the US and Mexico, the Mexican economy minister Guajardo said NAFTA talks at with the USTR will cover all outstanding issues in trade talks, but again reiterated that there will not be a deal on autos until all NAFTA issues are resolved.

* BOE: The BOE hiked its Bank Rate by 25bps, as expected; the initial hawkish surprise was that the decision was unanimous (8-1 or 7-2 were the consensus). Inflation forecasts were little changed from the May projections, and growth was nudged up slightly. Analysts at Lloyds noted, however, that the updated inflation projections are premised on an additional 35bps of tightening over the next three years (over and above the 25bp increase delivered today), suggesting that the BOE would need to raise rates by more than the markets are currently expecting, especially if it intends to bring inflation back to target over a more conventional timeframe. (After the meeting, Governor Carney said that one rate hike a year for the next few years will, more or less, get inflation back to the 2% target over the horizon). Overall, the MPC’s take on the outlook for the UK remains relatively unchanged, Lloyds says: “The economy is expected to remain relatively resilient, while disappointing productivity growth will continue to see the limited amount of spare capacity that exists in the economy, to be used up relatively quickly, necessitating further increases in interest rates over the forecast horizon.” Of course, the Bank’s policy path is contingent upon Brexit, and BOE's Carney said that the Bank is ready for any potential outcome, working with Finance Ministry and ECB to manage Brexit risks that it cannot solve itself; Carney also said there is a wide range of outcomes for Brexit, if there is a major shift due to Brexit talks that is deflationary, or creates an extreme trade-off, that could have consequences for monetary policy – in later comments, Carney said BoE is prepared to cut interest rates back again, depending upon how Brexit negotiations go.

* BREXIT: EU Brexit negotiator Barnier tweeted that Brexit negotiation can reach good outcome. “We must solve withdrawal issues including Ireland/Northern Ireland,” adding that the EU wants new partnership with the UK on security and with an ambitious free trade agreement at its heart.” Barneir believes this can be achieved based on the EU’s precious four principles.

* BANXICO: Mexico Central Bank maintains rates at 7.75%, as expected, in an unanimous decision. The Board says it will maintain prudent policy stance going forward, and it will follow closely the potential pass through from the peso, relative monetary stance with the US, as well as domestic slack. It also repeated its language that the balance of risks to inflation had an upward bias, balance of risks to growth has a downward bias.

* SPX +0.5% at 2827, NDX +1.36% at 7372, DJI -0.03% at 25328. SECTORS: Tech +1.2%, consumer non cyclicals +1.0%, utilities +0.7%, consumer non-cyclicals +0.6%, healthcare +0.4%, telecoms +0.2%, industrials +0.0%, financials -0.1%, energy -0.5%, materials -0.8%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) became the first USD 1tln company as shares briefly breached 207.04, however, sellers emerged as the valuation was realised. McDonald’s (MCD) were hit after reports in Business Insider that 350 French Branches have cases of Listeria.

* EARNINGS: Tesla (TSLA) lost more than was expected, however, its revenues beat expectations. Tesla’s cash outflow fell from $390mln in Q1 to $130mln in Q2 and also stated most of the cost restructuring took place in Q2, and it announced in the following quarter it expects to produce 50-55k Model 3s, but said the deliveries should exceed that; it also announced it will be sustainably profitable from Q3 onwards. After the report,  CEO Elon Musk apologised to analysts for his ‘bad behaviour’ in the last conference call where he stated the questions were ‘boring and bonehead’. The apology did benefit the stock as in aftermarket trade share price surged further to highs of ~11%. T-Mobile (TMUS) also reported an EPS beneath the consensus view, but revenues were stronger.

* M&A: Kraft Heinz (KHC) is said to have not made a bid for Pinnacle Foods (PF) in 2017; earlier in the week there was speculation Kraft Heinz could be a potential suitor for Campbell Soup (CPB), after it may be pushed for a sale by Dan Loeb’s Third Point. After Wednesdays speculation that Carl Icahn may aim to block Cigna’s (CI) $67bln takeover of Express Scripts (ESRX), Cigna’s CEO announced they are confident shareholders will approve the deal and it was also reported that Icahn only holds a 1.2% stake in the name.

* WTI (U8) SETTLES $1.30 HIGHER AT $68.96; BRENT (V8) SETTLES $1.06 HIGHER AT $73.45. Oil trades higher, despite data this week showing that supply continues to rise, and inventories are building. Russia crude production rose by 150k BPD in July, taking it 11.21mln BPD. Saudis cut official selling price to Asia by 70 cents, according to sources, which one analyst said reflects a need to trim prices if they hope to sell more barrels, which Citi says is also consistent with the ongoing contango spread in Brent. Traders were also citing a Bloomberg survey, which was said to show analysts forecasting OPEC production will rise by 300k BPD to 32.6mln BPD in July. And against that news flow, this week’s inventory data showed surprise builds, and now has analysts focussing on tomorrow’s Baker Hughes rig count data – one analyst noted that even a small addition of rigs could be enough to shake the crude market, given its sensitivity, at the moment. However, there were some bullish catalysts, and while they do not individually explain why oil is firm on Thursday, collectively, they may have provided bulls with the needed ammo: Singapore fuel stocks slipped to a nine-year low. Additionally, Genscape’s latest forecast for Cushing stocks was said to show a draw of 1.1mln bbls vs last Friday.

* US 10YR T-NOTES SETTLE HIGHER BY 5 TICKS AT 119-10+: Treasuries were higher and the curve modestly bull-steepened on Thursday. There was some selling action after a weak JGB auction overnight, and after the BOE’s rate decision, the complex also found sellers in the first instance. Analysts at IGM suggested that there was some short-covering ahead of Friday’s payrolls data, while the belly of the curve was bolstered by a block trade in the five-year space.

* DXY: Continued trade tensions kept the USD in positive territory, after the USTR was instructed to study raising tariffs on Chinese goods, and accordingly, the DXY once again above 95.0. JPY was also finding buyers, and while USDJPY is flat heading into Asia, EURJPY, AUDJPY and GBPJPY are all off by between 0.6% and 0.8%. One bank observes that US trade rhetoric has once again intensified as the US economy continues to show strength – as noted by the FOMC on Wednesday. Traders will be eyeing Friday’s payrolls data, particular the AHE metrics, for signs that this continues, which ING says may keep the USD strong and EM on the back foot, and commodity FX getting hit despite higher oil prices.

* GBP: Although the BOE lifted rates by 25bps, the pound has stumbled lower against both the USD and the EUR. Initially the pound rose on the decision, and the unanimous vote to hike rates, but during the press conference with Governor Carney, sellers emerged. There have been a number of narratives offered for the selling, with the Bank stressing that any future rate rises are likely to be gradual and limited (as it has suggested previously), and the current market rate path is flatter than it was in May, implying a rate of 0.9% in one-year (ie. another hike by then), and 1.0% in two-years, and 1.1% in three-years. Perhaps it was due to Carney once again flagging up Brexit risks suggesting that there is a wide range of outcomes for Brexit, if there is a major shift due to Brexit talks that is deflationary, or creates an extreme trade-off, that could have consequences for monetary policy. The net result was GBP conceding the 1.31 handle, though just manages to keep the 1.30 level.

* COMING-UP: US NONFARM PAYROLLS: The BLS will release July’s Employment Situation Report at 1330BST/0830EDT on 3rd August 2018. Headline payrolls expected to slow modestly to 190k after printing north of 200k in the past two months. Markets to focus on average hourly earnings as Fed seeks wage growth. subject: Daily FX Wrap: far from ‘super’ Thursday for the Pound
content:
GBP

Sterling was under pressure ahead of the BoE rate decision with Cable losing 1.3100+ status and retreating to around 1.3070 after breaching support just below the big figure and triggering stops, but knee-jerked higher when the MPC delivered a widely forecast ¼ point hike by a 9-0 vote vs 7-2 consensus. However, the rebound back above 1.3100 was short-lived as Governor Carney stressed the gradual pace of future tightening towards a flatter peak and with Brexit conditionality around the various scenarios including a cliff-edge or no deal worst case. The Pound slumped to circa 1.3015 in response, while Eur/Gbp climbed back over 0.8900 before regaining some composure.

JPY

The sole G10 gainer vs a broadly bid Usd on stronger safe-haven properties than the Greenback, as the US and China both hardened stances on reciprocal import tariffs. Usd/Jpy retreated further from 112.00+ peaks having closed below a key fib (112.19) yesterday, while Jpy crosses declined across the board.

AUD/NZD

On the back foot from the start of Thursday’s EU session (and prior to that once the benefit of much better than forecast Aussie trade data wore off) and extending losses vs their US peer in line with the Cny and Cnh (latter down to 6.8650+ vs the Usd at worst) on the aforementioned ramped up US vs China trade stand-off. Aud/Usd almost hit 0.7350 where a 1 bn option expiry ran off, but not quite, while the Kiwi fell to 0.6750 as the antipodean Dollar cross rebounded back over 1.0900.

EUR  

Broadly trading in tandem with overall Usd moves and risk sentiment, but just holding above 1.1600 having breached or closely tested several bearish technical levels (1.1648, 1.1616 and 1.1605). The headline pair also had 2+ bn option expries in view at 1.1600-10 and 1.1625-35.

CAD/CHF

Both held up relatively well against the Usd and within ranges, with the Loonie containing the downside ahead of 1.3050 and Franc limiting losses to less than 0.9950, while gaining vs the Eur (sub-1.1550) following beats on Swiss retail sales and the manufacturing PMI.

EM

Amidst widespread weakness across the region, Lira, Rouble and Rand losses were more pronounced and over 1% vs the Usd on a mixture of ongoing investor angst about US sanctions and bearish domestic factors. However, Usd/Try managed to pare some losses off a new record low beyond 5.0900 after reports that US Secretary of State Pompeo and Turkey’s Foreign Affairs have arranged to meet.

DXY  

Just off best levels a fraction above 95.000 and now looking towards Friday’s NFP report to justify the Fed’s broadly upbeat view of the economy and keep the index in the ascendency.

JPY

The sole G10 gainer vs a broadly bid Usd on stronger safe-haven properties than the Greenback, as the US and China both hardened stances on reciprocal import tariffs. Usd/Jpy retreated further from 112.00+ peaks having closed below a key fib (112.19) yesterday, while Jpy crosses declined across the board.

AUD/NZD

On the back foot from the start of Thursday’s EU session (and prior to that once the benefit of much better than forecast Aussie trade data wore off) and extending losses vs their US peer in line with the Cny and Cnh (latter down to 6.8650+ vs the Usd at worst) on the aforementioned ramped up US vs China trade stand-off. Aud/Usd almost hit 0.7350 where a 1 bn option expiry ran off, but not quite, while the Kiwi fell to 0.6750 as the antipodean Dollar cross rebounded back over 1.0900.

EUR  

Broadly trading in tandem with overall Usd moves and risk sentiment, but just holding above 1.1600 having breached or closely tested several bearish technical levels (1.1648, 1.1616 and 1.1605). The headline pair also had 2+ bn option expries in view at 1.1600-10 and 1.1625-35.

CAD/CHF

Both held up relatively well against the Usd and within ranges, with the Loonie containing the downside ahead of 1.3050 and Franc limiting losses to less than 0.9950, while gaining vs the Eur (sub-1.1550) following beats on Swiss retail sales and the manufacturing PMI.

EM

Amidst widespread weakness across the region, Lira, Rouble and Rand losses were more pronounced and over 1% vs the Usd on a mixture of ongoing investor angst about US sanctions and bearish domestic factors. However, Usd/Try managed to pare some losses off a new record low beyond 5.0900 after reports that US Secretary of State Pompeo and Turkey’s Foreign Affairs have arranged to meet.

DXY  

Just off best levels a fraction above 95.000 and now looking towards Friday’s NFP report to justify the Fed’s broadly upbeat view of the economy and keep the index in the ascendency.

BoE QIR Summary: Forecasts little changed from the May QIR. BoE announces r* rate projection
content:
Forecasts*:

GDP Growth: 2018 Q3: 1.5% (Prev.1.4%), 2019 Q3: 1.8% (Prev. 1.7%), 2020 Q3: 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%), 2021 Q3: 1.7%

CPI Inflation: 2018 Q3: 2.5% (Prev. 2.4%), 2019 Q3: 2.2% (Prev. 2.1%), 2020 Q3: 2.1% (Prev. 2.0%), 2021 Q3: 2.0

Unemployment Rate: 2018 Q3: 4.0% (Prev. 4.1%), 2019 Q3: 3.9% (Prev. 4.0%), 2020 Q3 3.9% (Prev. 4.0%), 2021 Q3: 3.9%

Average Weekly Earnings: 2018: 2.5% (Prev. 2.75%), 2019: 3.25% (Prev. 3.25%), 2020: 3.5% (Prev. 3.5%)

*Above forecasts are based on the path for the Bank rate reaching 1.1% by mid-2021

Key judgements:

1. Global demand grows at above-potential rates

2. Net trade and business investment continue to support UK activity, while consumption growth remains modest

3. Demand growth outstrips subdued potential supply growth, and a margin of excess demand emerges, pushing up domestic cost growth

4. Domestic inflationary pressures continue to build over the forecast period, while external cost pressures ease

r*: The BoE has for the first time published it’s r* (equilibrium Bank Rate) which would be the rate at which, if the economy started at a position with no output gap and inflation at target, would sustain output at potential and inflation at the target. The BoE notes that, when adding the BoE’s 2% inflation target to the 0-1% current real term r* rate this gives a nominal estimation for r* in the range of 2-3%.

subject: BoE August Meeting Summary: BoE votes 9-0 to lift rates by 25bps from 0.50% to 0.75%
content:
Key judgements:

  • Vote split on the base rate: 9-0 in favour of lifting the Bank Rate by 25bps to 0.75%
  • Vote split on corporate bonds: 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of corporate bonds
  • Vote split on APF: 9-0 in favour of maintaining the current stock of UK government bond purchases
  • Since the May QIR, the near-term outlook has evolved broadly in-line with the MPC’s expectations; recent data appears to confirm that the dip in output in Q1 was temporary with momentum recovering Q2
  • Growth: GDP in the three months to May printed at 0.2%; in-line with the MPC’s expectations. For Q2 as a whole, the MPC continues to expect a pickup in growth to 0.4%. Limited business surveys available point to a similar level of growth in Q3.
  • Inflation: The 2.4% print in June was below Bank forecasts but the downside was concentrated in a small number of volatile components
  • Rates: Were the economy to develop broadly inline with the August QIR projections, an ongoing tightening of monetary policy over the forecast period would be warranted. Any future rate rises are likely to be gradual and to a limited extent
  • Brexit: MPC recognises that the economic outlook could be influenced significantly by responses to the UK’s withdrawal from the EU
  • Wages: Pay growth (ex-bonus) had broadly been in-line with Bank expectations. A number of proximate indicators support the view that the pay environment has been strengthening further.
  • Labour market: Unemployment is low and is expected to fall a little further
  • Slack: MPC continues to judge that the UK economy has a very limited degree of slack
  • Read full release here

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US President Trump instructs USTR to consider 25% tariffs, instead of 10%, on USD 200bln of Chinese goods
  • USD strengthening and equities sliding on tariff concerns
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, BoE rate decision, minutes and QIR, US weekly jobs, factory orders and a slew of large cap earnings

ASIA

Asian equity markets were weaker across the board with sentiment weighed by increased global trade tensions after officials confirmed US President Trump instructed Trade Representative Lighthizer to consider a higher tariff of 25% on USD 200bln of goods from China which had earlier warned of retaliation. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower with the mining sector the worst performer in Australia amid losses in Rio Tinto following a miss on earnings, while a firmer currency, various corporate updates and weak US sales among automakers dampened Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.0%) took the brunt of the increased US tariff threats as well as further inaction by the PBoC which refrained from conducting reverse repos for a 10th consecutive occasion. 10yr JGBs were choppy and initially continued on from yesterday’s slump at the open as the 10yr yield rose to its highest since February last year of 0.145%. However, yields then pulled back to provide much needed reprieve for JGBs which were also supported amid safe-haven flows. In addition, the latest securities flows data showed foreign investors upped their purchases of Japanese bonds by around 9-fold from the prior week, while Daiwa also suggested there should be good demand for 10yr JGBs at yields between 0.15%-0.20% at least until next BoJ policy meeting. Today’s 10yr year auction was another catalyst for price action with all metrics pointing to a weaker result which saw 10yr JGBs decline nearly 30 ticks, before bouncing back towards 150.00.

US President Trump asked USTR to consider 25% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods, while officials also commented that stronger actions are needed on China but added that President Trump is open to negotiating with the Chinese President. China Commerce Ministry said China will have to fight back against the US to defend its dignity and people's interests; adding China upholds using dialogue to resolve disputes. (Newswires/ CNBC)

Indian retaliatory tariffs on US good may be delayed by 45 days, according to sources. (CNBC TV18)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7942 (Prev. 6.8293)

EU/UK/US

German sources denied that Germany is willing to offer UK PM May a vague Brexit deal to prevent the UK crashing out of the EU without an agreement. (Guardian)

UK environment minister Gove has privately discussed a backstop plan that would keep the UK in the EU single market if PM May’s Brexit strategy failed. (FT)

EU Producer Prices MM Jun 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires)

EU Producer Prices YY Jun 3.6% vs. Exp. 3.5% (Prev. 3.0%). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities trade firmly in the red (Eurostoxx 50 -1.3%) as sentiment is soured amid the rise in global trade tensions after officials confirmed US President Trump instructed Trade Representative Lighthizer to consider a higher tariff of 25% on USD 200bln of goods from China which had earlier warned of retaliation. China’s MOFCOM replied that China will fight back to defend its people’s interests and dignity. Germany’s DAX 30 is heavily underperforming, dragged down by heavyweight Siemens (-4.8%) following earnings, while Commerzbank (-4.5%), Deutsche Bank (-3.3%) and the German auto names also pressure the index. Material names continue to underperform, on the back of softer base metal prices. As such, we see UK miners resting at the bottom of the FTSE.

Other notable post-earning movers include: LSE (+2.6%), Altice (-14.5%), Hugo Boss (-6.0%) and Inmarsat (-4.9%)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have both retreated further from best levels, but the latter is now markedly underperforming having dipped below 122.00 to 121.99 (-13 ticks vs +7 ticks at best) on the back of a significant UK construction PMI beat that should have put any residual doubts about a BoE hike later to rest, before rebounding to 122.21. Meanwhile, the 10 year German benchmark is probing fresh Eurozone peaks at 161.42 (+51 ticks vs +14 ticks at the 161.05 low), with some underlying/renewed support coming via another downturn in Italian BTPs. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are closer to overnight highs and the curve fractionally flatter amidst more Chinese verbal warnings about retaliation against latest more penal US tariffs, and ahead of a busy post-Fed agenda before NFP on Friday. 

FX

USD - The Greenback is broadly firmer in wake of the latest FOMC statement that saw growth, inflation and labour market assessments all upgraded to underpin September rate hike expectations and keep the Fed on track to deliver another ¼ point tightening by year end. Heightened trade and other global tensions have also boosted the Buck as the DXY nudges back up to 95.000 having hit lows very close to the big figure below just 2 days ago.

GBP - In stark contrast, the Pound has been on the back foot even though the BoE is almost unanimously expected to raise rates by 25 bp at midday, and barely derived any support or traction from a much stronger than forecast UK construction PMI. Cable remains sub-1.3100 having hit a circa 1.3070 low after support around 1.3095 also gave way and stops were reportedly tripped from 1.3090. Back to ‘super’ Thursday, many believe that guidance and the general tone from the MPC minutes will be cautious, if not dovish, with risks to growth and inflation from ongoing Brexit uncertainty and global trade wars likely to be flagged and highlighted in latest QIR projections.

AUD/NZD - The other G10 laggards and both back under big figure levels (0.7400 and 0.6800 respectively) vs their US counterpart on the aforementioned ramp up in US-China import tariff threats and counter measures or verbal retaliation. The Aud got a temporary lift overnight from a significantly wider than anticipated Aussie trade surplus, but faded above the round number yet again and could also be wary about a hefty option expiry (1 bn) at the 0.7350 strike.

EUR - The single currency has lost more traction vs the Usd on the downturn in risk sentiment, and retreated further from 1.1700 towards 1.1600 having breached Fib support near 1.1616 and a daily cloud base at 1.1648 on the way down. However, more layered expiry interest in decent size between 1.1600-10 and 1.1625-35 (both in 1.1 bn) could exert some directional influence ahead of and into the NY cut.

CHF - Somewhat mixed after Wednesday’s Swiss national day break with declines vs the Dollar towards 0.9950, but outperformance against the Eur in wake of stronger than expected retail sales data and manufacturing PMI – cross hovering just below 1.1550.

CAD - Back below 1.3000 vs its US rival, but not really due to anything Loonie-specific.

EM -Broad losses vs the generally bid Usd, but the Lira’s almost inevitable further depreciation on latest US sanction proposals down through 5.0000 is eye-catching as the Try tumbles to fresh all time lows (circa 5.0900 at one stage).

COMMODITIES

 WTI and Brent slip lower with the complex pressured by USD strength following the latest tariff news. Energy news flow remains light, however, sources reported that  Russia, the largest oil producer,  is forecasting  an output around 11.2mln bpd to the year-end. Of note: Russia’s July oil production stood at 11.2mln bpd (vs. June output of 10.93mln bpd). Meanwhile, the Shanghai International Energy Exchange are looking into the possibility of setting up a market maker scheme for crude oil futures after the exchange asked brokers to help boost trading volumes and liquidity.

Spot gold is flat as USD strength outweighs safe-haven flows. Copper continues its decline amid demand concerns fuelled by the rise in trade tensions.

content: Gilts have traded marginally firmer for choice at the start of super Thursday at Threadneedle Street within 122.19-10 early Liffe parameters vs yesterday’s 122.12 close, in contrast to Short Sterling contracts that are treading more cautiously ahead of high noon and the post-meeting QIR presser between flat and 1 tick adrift. A 25 bp hike is largely priced in, but the MPC vote split, minutes and aforementioned inflation report will be key in terms of determining whether the BoE is planning to tighten policy further this year or shifts to a neutral/2-way stance in case Brexit blows up and/or trade tensions escalate to all out war proportions. Hence, it is far from over until the Old Lady has had her say, and the construction PMI will likely be just a starter before the main course.

content: This week’s roller-coaster ride continues for core bonds, with some respite in JGBs overnight (albeit after another slide and rally in yields) and broader risk sentiment soured by confirmation that the US is upping the ante on Chinese tariffs, reviving demand for safer-havens like the German 10 year debt future. However, the rebound appears fragile again amidst the overall bear re-steepening trend that has only marginally paused in wake of the FOMC last night as the Fed fuelled expectations of 2 more hikes this year. Ahead, Thursday’s Eurozone agenda is sparse in terms of data with just PPI due, but supply could be an issue given hefty multi-tranche auctions from Spain and France. Back to Eurex, Bunds are currently mid-range between 161.11-23 vs yesterday’s 160.91 close.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

2nd August 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were weaker across the board with sentiment weighed by increased global trade tensions after officials confirmed US President Trump instructed Trade Representative Lighthizer to consider a higher tariff of 25% on USD 200bln of goods from China which had earlier warned of retaliation. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower with the mining sector the worst performer in Australia amid losses in Rio Tinto following a miss on earnings, while a firmer currency, various corporate updates and weak US sales among automakers dampened Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) took the brunt of the increased US tariff threats as well as further inaction by the PBoC which refrained from conducting reverse repos for a 10th consecutive occasion. 10yr JGBs were choppy and initially continued on from yesterday’s slump at the open as the 10yr yield rose to its highest since February last year of 0.145%. However, yields then pulled back to provide much needed reprieve for JGBs which were also supported amid safe-haven flows. In addition, the latest securities flows data showed foreign investors upped their purchases of Japanese bonds by around 9-fold from the prior week, while Daiwa also suggested there should be good demand for 10yr JGBs at yields between 0.15%-0.20% at least until next BoJ policy meeting. Today’s 10yr year auction was another catalyst for price action with all metrics pointing to a weaker result which saw 10yr JGBs decline nearly 30 ticks, before bouncing back towards 150.00.

FTSE

Elsewhere, the co. announced it has set a future course with vision 2020+, with the aim of giving the co.’s individual businesses more entrepreneurial freedom under a strong siemens brand. It’s organisational level of divisions will be removed; regional organisation will be realigned to increase customer orientation and to streamline the HQ. Siemens says its annual revenue growth rate and profit margin of the industrial businesses are expected to increase by 2% in the medium term. Says its basic EPS is expected to grow faster than revenue for the same period. The new structure will take place on October 1st ,2018. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • The Fed stood pat on rates as expected with little in the way of fireworks from the release. Markets continue to back a September hike at the FOMC
  • Asian equity markets were weaker across the board with sentiment weighed on by increased global trade tensions after US officials confirmed recent reports about potential hikes to Chinese tariffs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK construction PMI, BoE rate decision, minutes and QIR, US weekly jobs, factory orders and a slew of large cap earnings

FOMC

US Fed Funds Target Rate 1.75 - 2.00% vs. Exp. 1.75 - 2.00% (Prev. 1.75 - 2.00%). (Newswires)
- Fed stated that economic activity has been rising at a strong rate, job gains have been strong recently, unemployment rate stayed low, inflation remains near two percent and that long-term inflation expectations are little changed.
- Fed also expects further gradual increases in fed funds rate will be consistent with sustained economic expansion, strong jobs market and inflation objective, while it repeats monetary policy stance remains accommodative and that near-term risks to economy are roughly balanced.

There was also no major commentary on trade wars despite concerns that agents’ expressed in the latest Beige Book and accordingly, the market reaction was muted since there was no real new information and the outcome was generally in line with expectations.
 

ASIA

Asian equity markets were weaker across the board with sentiment weighed by increased global trade tensions after officials confirmed US President Trump instructed Trade Representative Lighthizer to consider a higher tariff of 25% on USD 200bln of goods from China which had earlier warned of retaliation. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower with the mining sector the worst performer in Australia amid losses in Rio Tinto following a miss on earnings, while a firmer currency, various corporate updates and weak US sales among automakers dampened Tokyo trade. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) took the brunt of the increased US tariff threats as well as further inaction by the PBoC which refrained from conducting reverse repos for a 10th consecutive occasion. 10yr JGBs were choppy and initially continued on from yesterday’s slump at the open as the 10yr yield rose to its highest since February last year of 0.145%. However, yields then pulled back to provide much needed reprieve for JGBs which were also supported amid safe-haven flows. In addition, the latest securities flows data showed foreign investors upped their purchases of Japanese bonds by around 9-fold from the prior week, while Daiwa also suggested there should be good demand for 10yr JGBs at yields between 0.15%-0.20% at least until next BoJ policy meeting. Today’s 10yr year auction was another catalyst for price action with all metrics pointing to a weaker result which saw 10yr JGBs decline nearly 30 ticks, before bouncing back towards 150.00.

US President Trump asked USTR to consider 25% tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods, while officials also commented that stronger actions are needed on China but added that President Trump is open to negotiating with the Chinese President. (CNBC)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7942 (Prev. 6.8293)

UK/EU

German sources denied that Germany is willing to offer UK PM May a vague Brexit deal to prevent the UK crashing out of the EU without an agreement. In separate news, there were also comments from EU’s Barnier that he is optimistic Brexit talks will result in satisfaction. (Guardian/Newswires)

UK environment minister Gove has privately discussed a backstop plan that would keep the UK in the EU single market if PM May’s Brexit strategy failed. (FT)

UK PM May has been warned that UK-only passport lines at airports will simply generate longer queues for Britons at home and abroad. (Times)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was flat for most the session in a continuation of the prior day’s indecision and after the FOMC failed to trigger any significant reaction. EUR/USD was lacklustre after having recently failed to reclaim the 1.1700 handle and GBP/USD initially bided its time ahead of the BoE’s Super Thursday where the central bank is expected to hike rates by 25bps, although pressure later resumed as risk sentiment continued to deteriorate. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses were dampened amid the risk averse tone and AUD/USD retreated below 0.7400 as a larger than expected Trade Surplus only provided brief support against the gloomy backdrop of recent commodity declines and trade-related concerns, while TRY printed fresh record lows against the USD and briefly broke above 5.00 on news of US sanctions on Turkey.

Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(Jun) 1873M vs. Exp. 900M (Prev. 827M). (Newswires)
Australian Exports (Jun) M/M 3% (Prev. 4.0%)
Australian Imports (Jun) M/M -1% (Prev. 3.0%)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which prices mostly languished near the prior day’s lows amid a wide spread risk averse tone due to increased tariff concerns. As such, WTI crude futures were relatively flat as attempts to nurse some of the losses from the surprise builds in API and DoE crude inventory reports was thwarted by resistance around the USD 68.00/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold prices only saw marginal gains as support from safe-haven flows was counterbalanced by the greenback, while copper continued on its downward path amid trade concerns and weakness in Chinese metal prices.

China is said to plan restricting steel output in more cities during winter. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

Israeli PM Netanyahu warned that Iran will find an international coalition against them which includes Israel if it attempts to block the Bab-el-Mandeb straits, while there were separate reports that Iran is said to be readying military exercises in the Persian Gulf. (Newswires/CNN)

White House said the US is sanctioning Turkish officials over the detention of American Pastor Brunson and had reportedly prepared a list of Turkish entities as well as individuals that it will target, while the Turkish Foreign Ministry strongly condemned the US sanctions and that it will retaliate against the hostile stance by the US. (Newswires)


US

Yields were higher and the Treasury curve bear-steepened on Wednesday, amid decent ADP data that hints at a solid NFP report on Friday, as well as increased issuance due out of the US Treasury over the coming quarter (see below), while the FOMC’s latest statement still alludes to a course of gradual hikes that will see the fed funds rate target lifted on another two occasion in 2018. 10-year yields once again returned to above 3.00% (just) rising around 4bps in the session, while longer-dated yields were up by around 5bps at settlement. US 10YR T-notes settled 8 ticks lower at 119-05+.

Senior Mexican official said Mexico and US are getting close to a deal on autos and rules of origin of NAFTA, while the official added the US is still pressing for a sunset clause and that Mexico are suggesting this could be reviewed every 5 years. (Newswires)

US President Trump stated that he is open to shutting the government down, before or after the election. (Newswires)

Trump lawyer Giuliani stated that the President will not terminate the Mueller probe, while there were separate reports that Special Counsel Mueller wants to ask President Trump regarding obstruction of justice. (CNN/ABC)
